text: Mac Miller blue slide park
ha ha ha hi everyone my needle drops
Anthony fanta know the Internet's
busiest music nerd here and it's time
for a review the new Mac Miller LP blue
slide park this this this kids a
Pittsburgh rapper
this is his full-length debut album
after a series of some pretty decent
mixtapes and I'm not really sure why but
this kid seems to have a ton of fans but
a lot a lot of haters people hate this
kid and while I don't really quite get
the fanatic love I don't get the insane
hatred either I mean I kind of consider
myself middle-of-the-road
maybe a casual Mac Miller fan a lot of
Mac Miller's older material to me is
just kind of from the heart hip hop kind
of painting a fun and and silly picture
of this suburban dope smoking kid who's
very nice and approachable likes to
party and has a dream that's kind of a
subject in a style that hasn't faired
all that well in hip hop
the most recent character besides Mac
Miller to kind of do a similar thing is
is Asher Roth when he put out that album
asleep in the bread aisle in 2009 and
yeah the rapping and the lyricism on
that album is pretty average it's pretty
bad sometimes too but there was a bigger
issue with what people had beef with in
regards to that album and I think it was
kind of a problem of trust I kind of
felt like that album was a label
manufactured trick to kind of get pot
smoking Xbox playin keg standing college
kids to buy a rap CD Mac Miller on the
other hand that question of authenticity
is not there Mac Miller
is actually that guy and to be blunt
about it I'm not
big on this album either for me the
biggest issue on this thing is that you
know this is a full-length debut
official album I kind of expected to be
wowed a little bit but his lyricism and
his flow haven't really progressed
matured anything this album is just kind
of loaded with fun shallow slightly
egotistical party pop rap that is
peppered with you know
cultural references it's not terrible
but I'm not really a fan and it's not so
much what Mac Miller says but kind of
how he says it because in a way Mac
Miller kind of reminds me of the Beastie
Boys when they first came out they both
definitely cater to a similar
demographic and they shared lyrics about
parties and getting wasted but at the
end of the day I think when you kind of
dug below the surface of the Beastie
Boys there was kind of this
tongue-in-cheek thing about them where
they were very well aware that what they
were doing was ridiculous I don't really
get that vibe with Mac Miller especially
on this album because on this LP he
seriously tries to create a song where
he puts together the soundtrack for the
park where he used to hang out at at
night and get high and there's even like
you know police what kind of going on
and off oh no the police are here we're
hanging out at a playground getting high
it's kind of embarrassing the only thing
that I think has really changed about
this album lyrically is just the story
the narrative just the things that Mac
Miller is is rapping about and you know
at first this kid kind of came off as as
being very hungry and and and and
looking for fame but that's gone now and
the discussion has turned to dealing
with that Fame dealing with haters
dealing with fans dealing with the money
dealing with the popularity just dealing
with it and constantly assuring me and
his fans that he hasn't changed
he ain't changing nothing's changed he's
still the same
and that may very well be true but I
don't care
I would rather Mac Miller change and
then make an interesting album then not
change and just keep making the same
albums over and over and over again the
beats on this thing I think are really
where things kind of go downhill and I'm
really surprised at that because most of
the beat choices on his last mixtape
we're pretty good I kind of welcomed
that mixtape because it moved away from
the silly and sugary beats I was hearing
on kids that I was hearing on best day
ever
you know tracks like the spins and then
senior skip day that kind of made me
cringe blue slide park by comparison is
like 50% sugary candy cane nonsense it
gets worst on the track up all night
where you've got this like pop punk rock
drumbeat mixed together with these
walking on sunshine piano chords it
sounds like a party song for kids who
still have a curfew the heavy bass hits
on smile' back and and my team kind of
feel like like Young Money beats or
something and the hooks on tracks like
gold and diamonds and and under the
weather are so sweet they kind of feel
like trying to swallow an entire sleeve
of Sour Patch Kids without chewing it
just doesn't even feel like hip-hop at
this point it just kind of feels like
pop instrumentals but with rapping over
them the only thing that's really
appealing about Mac Miller is his story
his fun personality and his kind of
underdog image well that's appealing
depending on who you are there are some
decent clams casino beats on here and
the track party on Fifth Ave kind of
cuts out the horn phrase from let me
clear my throat and then puts it over
this more like Club beat it's kind of an
interesting reimagined version but a
little bit overall I just could not
really sit through this thing it was
kind of redundant it just felt a little
pointless in that Mac Miller wasn't
really saying any
thing a lot of the time he was just kind
of dropping mediocre punchlines left and
right and when he wasn't doing that he
was kind of telling his personal story
about dealing with Fame and that really
didn't interest me I see it being
interesting to fans to people who have
watched him carry on this form so I'm
kind of feeling like a strong for to a
light five on this but what do you think
of this thing do you love it do you hate
it why and what should I review next you
have any Fantana Mac Miller
Bret
[Music]
